title: Engineering Science
subject: CTE: Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (2022-)

902FAA1044894D18AA5A3DDD2AC1D9B0.description:
determine the angle needed to launch a projectile a specific range given the projectile's
initial velocity.

C5F8DFC5C05B4EB4B729CD0B29E84139.description: calculate the X and Y components of an object in projectile motion; and

3775442465EC445EB711186DBD6606BA.description:
calculate experimentally the acceleration due to gravity given data from a free-fall
device;

1193F57EA0E24B22A72E08039E3925CF.description: calculate distance, displacement, speed, velocity, and acceleration from data;

C865641AA8684534B0121D05C55B3C42.description:
The student demonstrates an understanding of kinematics in one and two dimensions and applies
the concepts to real-world engineering design problems. The student is expected to:

737C21C3136142EB904FB72FD2D920A3.description: create a histogram to illustrate frequency distribution.

EBA4851BDC05441C9F900CB2349CAB4E.description: calculate data variation, including range, standard deviation, and variance; and

8B8CB60A8E9A444C84B7B15B748D963A.description: calculate the central tendency of a data array, including mean, median, and mode;

B138342FCD4742AFB6F60459F8D79073.description: apply Bayes's theorem to calculate the probability of multiple events occurring;

4FAEA8DB40A247E5A1831D4131D67CA0.description: apply AND, OR, and NOT logic to solve complex probability scenarios;

1764136EAC2F4958922499FAF2F8BAC0.description: calculate the theoretical probability that an event will occur;

486994A3D2704266A144D467E2B5B519.description:
The student demonstrates an understanding of statistics and applies the concepts to real-world
engineering design problems. The student is expected to:

E508B40A28AD4C3E9D89495ACAFEE286.description: calculate flow rate, flow velocity, and mechanical advantage in a hydraulic system.

A19C736B504B46208D091819EABB9558.description: calculate values in a pneumatic system using the ideal gas laws; and

3F795FF32475453A8BAAA544466D8067.description:
distinguish between gauge pressure and absolute pressure and between temperature and
absolute temperature;

A6004EFF0256418B8F8CC4FB98875EDC.description: use Pascal's Law to calculate values in a fluid power system;

03E50AD9D77544ACB5F0C632317B1592.description:
differentiate between pneumatic and hydraulic systems and between hydrodynamic and
hydrostatic systems;

E6259D77161D40D1BDA30D9339F69A81.description: identify and explain basic components and functions of fluid power devices;

8367B5D5D7CF47C7AF609093C8734B28.description:
The student demonstrates an understanding of fluid power systems and calculates values in a
variety of systems. The student is expected to:

2EE97877C812404992D0D60BEB62CE69.description:
judge between open- and closed-loop systems in order to select the most appropriate
system for a given technological problem.

026A5F229E6347A3BDD15CBC9B33491A.description:
select appropriate input and output devices based on the need of a technological system;
and

0EA152D405844B0982092C8A16D35FBD.description: create system control programs that use flowchart logic;

146E90CACB4941E3A57DCFF4BA38FF1F.description: create control system operating programs using computer software;

F0C026A6CB1A4D28A77C552B2F866017.description: create detailed flowcharts using a computer software application;

CD1191BF873248A7A98F571CEBE09C80.description:
The student understands that control systems are designed to provide consentient process control
and reliability and uses computer software to create flowcharts and control system operating
programs. The student is expected to:

D0C12ECC2D50459FBA786315A7124D0F.description:
identify and compare measurements and calculations of sample material properties such
as elastic range, proportional limit, modulus of elasticity, elastic limit, resilience, yield
point, plastic deformation, ultimate strength, failure, and ductility using stress-strain data

4C7F04151C944A3F932F39D9111D4FEC.description: identify and calculate test sample material properties using a stress-strain curve; and

303DDF8D84F648CDA6E30D3856ECEB16.description:
use material testing to determine a product's reliability, safety, and predictability in
function;

AEC08D34426D4477B2F4FAE31CE7043E.description: obtain measurements of material samples such as length, width, height, and mass;

B50E46697B16425696158EB2CD0CA630.description: use a design process and mathematical formulas to solve and document design problems;

CDB43571CD2B4FDAAA3C7520E588A0B1.description:
The student uses material testing to determine a product's function and performance. The student
is expected to:

70B1EDA8F5B54078AEFD0C79F0017CFC.description:

1F3401F0A68743CCACB304C89D6EA698.description:

conduct investigative non-destructive material property tests on selected common
household products;

3CD2EEF0F808454EBF2C932371B27D2F.description:
The student understands material properties and the importance of choosing appropriate materials

90560F972ED64CAC875C3B30868CF0A9.description: alculate external and internal forces in a statically determinate truss using translational and rotational equilibrium equations.

CBCB28A1E81941C2A250A052BDB3F15C.description: calculate unknown forces using equations of equilibrium; and

CF11F6EE9FA747AC8E780112F56A8AD8.description: calculate the X and Y components given a vector;

A62CE63E72F44BC8AF81F990606FAA58.description: identify properties of a vector, including magnitude and direction;

AB0150C38BC54FF0AA216912FE164939.description: differentiate between scalar and vector quantities;

3BC083B2574E499A9B2ED18E51BD2733.description: calculate moment of inertia of structural members;

662DD905A0254390A6A359AA7FBD601C.description: locate the centroid of structural members mathematically or experimentally;

9BB8104963624E95BF4AAD4E9608290F.description: illustrate, calculate, and experimentally measure all forces acting upon a given body;

FF00F960D71144928079C50E13374954.description:
The student understands the interaction of forces acting on a body and performs calculations
related to structural design. The student is expected to:

701606716BFF4A3F9BBCD6CEE9E1B615.description:

AEC2A6F7707841898AD9EA5261265DE0.description:
analyze how thermal energy transfer is affected by conduction, thermal resistance values,
convection, and radiation; and

2A2BE9B0FECC49C48F5829322875F1BF.description:
measure and analyze how thermal energy is transferred via convection, conduction, and
radiation;

C2908CFDBF084D04A355D0754009280E.description:
describe how hydrogen fuel cells create electricity and heat and how solar cells create
electricity;

00DF73C5077640CBB504B1F9797846AC.description:

forms;

929BFD736AB24F109B3F2406CBA11446.description: evaluate system energy requirements in order to select the proper energy source;

FD908E38ED6B4C7284E10B4EDB5B0DCE.description: explain the purpose of energy management;

EDEC8466A6CE44418C24D0738A6B07D7.description:
The student understands system energy requirements and how energy sources can be combined to
convert energy into useful forms. The student understands the relationships among material
conductivity, resistance, and geometry in order to calculate energy transfer and determine power

46D3D26123C84EDAABA180C244D0F428.description:

561254C26BF74CF594DEEB96A2FF6AD6.description: calculate power in a system that converts energy from electrical to mechanical; and

454AD31671754276B874C48E330C7139.description: define and calculate work and power in electrical systems;

478FF93397AF42129F0C5AEAF494263E.description: identify and categorize energy sources as nonrenewable, renewable, or inexhaustible;

EA3170B66B414596B5328287F9E6AE76.description:
The student understands energy sources, energy conversion, and circuits and performs calculations
related to work and power. The student is expected to:

09946EAF0EDA419097FB6E658FEDF2CD.description: calculate mechanical advantage and drive ratios of mechanisms.

1F9A4FA611A84835BA91212CBA1E0DB7.description: determine experimentally the efficiency of mechanical systems; and

B3CEA62834A54F2FA51169157700307D.description: calculate work and power in mechanical systems;

4221C9054D384DF5B5D7302ED59451B4.description: measure forces and distances related to a mechanism;

DB30894205EA4C0692405781E2F35972.description: distinguish between the six simple machines and their attributes and components;

D974D5AD7D4E4978A332C53FAF677E59.description:
explain how components, including gears, sprockets, pulley systems, and simple
machines, make up mechanisms;

D11D5EF955394EFE99C0F99AAC45A2F5.description:
explain the purpose and operation of components, including gears, sprockets, pulley

731191CC5A474368A0F7B1763A1580C7.description:
The student understands mechanisms, including simple and compound machines, and performs
calculations related to mechanical advantage, drive ratios, work, and power. The student is
expected to:

82E46F92CDBD4782B10A51754B0330BE.description: work as a member of a team to conduct research to develop a knowledge base, stimulate creative ideas, and make informed decisions.

9FAF89CFC4AA4ACFBC6DEEC4D135E125.description: use communication to achieve a desired goal within a team; and

330FB8C33C3848B4868A58D64BF128F2.description: use a design brief to identify problem specifications and establish project constraints;

EAED6A7B42244C0E96B5D1CA9C6E77AC.description: create solutions to existing problems using a design process;

120E9ACB3A5449799B44FA049E0268CC.description: solve design problems individually and in a team;

66AFBF95831E4188AD19390BB6FB5DDA.description:
The student demonstrates an understanding of design problems and works individually and as a
member of a team to solve design problems. The student is expected to:

B151461996B54D26B73832BC307B6EE9.description: demonstrate appropriate oral, written, and visual forms of technical communication.

CB61FF17BE7E4903AEACD8C1E76BC0D2.description: identify and differentiate between the different engineering disciplines; and

A2CD0AC14447490A830184D21E7E1134.description:
compare the roles or job descriptions for career opportunities in the fields of pure science,
engineering, and engineering technology;

DD27EE6D4804429D8949837759CD6138.description: differentiate between engineering and engineering technology;

A1971545A0D94217877BA1F437815630.description:
The student investigates engineering-related fields and career opportunities. The student is
expected to:

3B8EFE5F012043DBBDD160EBA74B6F79.description: evaluate models according to their limitations in representing objects or events.

4A5AF457EBDB4D3ABF27EEA797AC37E5.description: evaluate the impact of scientific research on society and the environment; and

C1205E0041DD4CD3931DC24A85D17029.description: draw inferences based on data related to promotional materials for products and services;

3DDA5B1272E44B91879ABD3A2F7D361F.description:
communicate and apply scientific information extracted from various sources such as
current events, news reports, published journal articles, and marketing materials;

8F39DA92C86745C5A59B2F65D27708EA.description:
in all fields of science, analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using
empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing,
including examining all sides of scientific evidence of those scientific explanations, so as
to encourage critical thinking;

D8EA527F4459426FBE627A5425EEA139.description:
The student uses critical thinking, scientific reasoning, and problem solving to make informed
decisions within and outside the classroom. The student is expected to:

522923ECC0D24CA2BE21D1A8C39507CC.description:
communicate valid conclusions supported by the data through methods such as lab
reports, labeled drawings, graphic organizers, journals, summaries, oral reports, and
technology-based reports.

2CF95AF0B6DB46438C5E5CC4A5551DF6.description: analyze, evaluate, make inferences, and predict trends from data; and

98CA885F04BD4006989158A34AD4B6B1.description:
collect and organize qualitative and quantitative data and make measurements with
accuracy and precision using tools such as spreadsheet software, data-collecting probes,
computers, standard laboratory glassware, microscopes, various prepared slides,
stereoscopes, electronic balances, micropipettors, hand lenses, surgical and imagining
equipment, thermometers, hot plates, lab notebooks or journals, timing devices, Petri
dishes, lab incubators, dissection equipment, and models, diagrams, or samples of
biological specimens or structures;

61C1013A0BFD4D8290D1A637F86194C6.description: distinguish between scientific hypotheses and scientific theories;

ADFCA278610D4DC09AB385DABAAA0629.description:
know scientific theories are based on natural and physical phenomena and are capable of
being tested by multiple independent researchers. Unlike hypotheses, scientific theories
are well-established and highly-reliable explanations, but they may be subject to change
as new areas of science and new technologies are developed;

F39110433CCF4D78B7158E45CFBDC0A5.description:
know that hypotheses are tentative and testable statements that must be capable of being
supported or not supported by observational evidence. Hypotheses of durable explanatory
power which have been tested over a wide variety of conditions are incorporated into
theories;

2CB9C3F8AE374ECE9FA15C2632A5DF64.description:
know the definition of science and understand that it has limitations, as specified in
subsection (b)(4) of this section;

EF61F184A0CA46448A7BB843370842EE.description:
The student uses scientific methods and equipment during laboratory and field investigations. The
student is expected to:

A3645C751EE84452994E674B718D88B7.description:
demonstrate an understanding of the use and conservation of resources and the proper
disposal or recycling of materials.

48BFE7426BEA485D93B0FB3A233E34B7.description: demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations; and

3E786E18F2944232804F4B9AD6D69394.description:
The student, for at least 40% of instructional time, conducts laboratory and field investigations
using safe, environmentally appropriate, and ethical practices. The student is expected to:

82FDDD6CCD6D4DAB9EFB46201431F809.description:
demonstrate punctuality, dependability, reliability, and responsibility in performing
assigned tasks as directed.

BEE69914D3B54402A0BA616426A3CF3A.description:
demonstrate time-management skills in prioritizing tasks, following schedules, and
performing goal-relevant activities in a way that produces efficient results; and

E544611A81C04363A079F1A2839B702E.description: present written and oral communication in a clear, concise, and effective manner;

C59BE34685004FBE93641D6B1E0E41F8.description:
show the ability to cooperate, contribute, and collaborate as a member of a group in an
effort to achieve a positive collective outcome;

B7CAE43B7B404B4394F86E74A1871E56.description:
demonstrate knowledge of how to dress appropriately, speak politely, and conduct
oneself in a manner appropriate for the profession;

47208AC5944B463AB32E3C875C1742C4.description:
The student demonstrates professional standards/employability skills as required by business and
industry. The student is expected to:

C2C37411DC954EBD916EEB16172089E4.description:
Statements that contain the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those
containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

D8B6E29F4D1D4CEC8FCD4825B4939BB8.description:
Students are encouraged to participate in extended learning experiences such as career and
technical student organizations and other leadership or extracurricular organizations.

A75745102B754986A1A19E27CB25FD76.description:
A system is a collection of cycles, structures, and processes that interact. All systems have basic
properties that can be described in space, time, energy, and matter. Change and constancy occur in
systems as patterns and can be observed, measured, and modeled. These patterns help to make
predictions that can be scientifically tested. Students should analyze a system in terms of its
components and how these components relate to each other, to the whole, and to the external
environment.

74F3BBC446334AB39F44CE5EC7CCACCF.description:
Scientific decision making is a way of answering questions about the natural world. Students
should be able to distinguish between scientific decision-making methods (scientific methods) and
ethical and social decisions that involve science (the application of scientific information).

0C31908647AF48928C676435C4C2FFF9.description:
Scientific inquiry is the planned and deliberate investigation of the natural world. Scientific
methods of investigation are experimental, descriptive, or comparative. The method chosen should
be appropriate to the question being asked.

973165DAF31D424B96A5E04E84DCA9B2.description:
Science, as defined by the National Academy of Sciences, is the "use of evidence to construct
testable explanations and predictions of natural phenomena, as well as the knowledge generated
through this process." This vast body of changing and increasing knowledge is described by
physical, mathematical, and conceptual models. Students should know that some questions are
outside the realm of science because they deal with phenomena that are not scientifically testable.

16D58BA5DE6C4C808C0FF4B545EB11B3.description:
Engineering Science is an engineering course designed to expose students to some of the major
concepts and technologies that they will encounter in a postsecondary program of study in any
engineering domain. Students will have an opportunity to investigate engineering and high-tech
careers. In Engineering Science, students will employ science, technology, engineering, and
mathematical concepts in the solution of real-world challenge situations. Students will develop
problem-solving skills and apply their knowledge of research and design to create solutions to
various challenges. Students will also learn how to document their work and communicate their
solutions to their peers and members of the professional community.

B4E7D2158A3E4C2E9204CAEA623D68D2.description:
The Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) Career Cluster focuses on
planning, managing, and providing scientific research and professional and technical services,
including laboratory and testing services, and research and development services.

A04FF33135C04528A6BC9786C6ACE3DB.description:
Career and technical education instruction provides content aligned with challenging academic
standards and relevant technical knowledge and skills for students to further their education and
succeed in current or emerging professions.

92D33A8BB3CD4D5BAED6C36FA7EA26F5.description:
General requirements. This course is recommended for students in Grades 10-12. Prerequisite: Algebra I
and Biology, Chemistry, Integrated Physics and Chemistry (IPC), or Physics. Recommended prerequisite:
Geometry. Students must meet the 40% laboratory and fieldwork requirement. This course satisfies a high
school science graduation requirement. Students shall be awarded one credit for successful completion of
this course.
